ticket.title: [PATCH] json validations errors for ActiveResource
ticket.original-body:
ActiveResource can interpret validations errors from xml body, but not from json and even worse : he tries to interpret json output as xml and parse it.
This patch adds json support for validations errors based on the work of Rick Olson. You can render errors in json like this : render :json => @person.errors.to_json, :status => 422

This patch adds json support for validations errors based on the work of Rick Olson. You can render errors in json like this : render :json => @person.errors.to_json, :status => 422

This patch adds json support for validations errors based on the work of Rick Olson. You can render errors in json like this : render :json => @person.errors.to_json, :status => 422

This patch adds json support for validations errors based on the work of Rick Olson. You can render errors in json like this : render :json => @person.errors.to_json, :status => 422

version.body: Our company faces the same problem. Why is this patch not accepted?
version.body-html: Our company faces the same problem. Why is this patch not accepted?

version.title: json validations errors for ActiveResource

version.body:
I tried to contact rails-core mailing list, but nobody answers. I also try to contact directly a member of the rails-core team who told me the patch seems good and should be applied within 2 weeks ... but that was 2 months ago and he does not answer me anymore.
I checked with both 2.3 and 3.0 branches and it still applies cleanly.
Maybe if you can move things on the mailing list, you can have this patch applied.
version.body-html:
I tried to contact rails-core mailing list, but nobody answers. I also try to contact directly a member of the rails-core team who told me the patch seems good and should be applied within 2 weeks ... but that was 2 months ago and he does not answer me anymore.

I checked with both 2.3 and 3.0 branches and it still applies cleanly.

Maybe if you can move things on the mailing list, you can have this patch applied.

version.diffable-attributes: --- :tag: 2-3-stable 2.3.x 2.x 3.0 activeresource active_resource bugmash json patch validation validations :milestone: 9903
version.tag: 2-3-stable 2.3.x 2.x 3.0 activeresource active_resource json patch validation validations
version.title: [PATCH] json validations errors for ActiveResource

version.body:
A change to ActiveResource::Validations was introduced in 2.3.4 which adds support for JSON errors:
This is looking for an exact match on Content-Type 'application/xml'. If, for example, the returned Content-Type is 'application/xml; charset=utf-8' then the error response is ignored.
version.body-html:
A change to ActiveResource::Validations was introduced in 2.3.4 which adds support for JSON errors:

This is looking for an exact match on Content-Type 'application/xml'. If, for example, the returned Content-Type is 'application/xml; charset=utf-8' then the error response is ignored.
version.tag: 2-3-stable 2.3.x 2.x 3.0 activeresource active_resource json patch validation validations
version.title: [PATCH] json validations errors for ActiveResource

version.tag: 2-3-stable 2.3.x 2.x 3.0 activeresource active_resource json patch validation validations
version.title: [PATCH] json validations errors for ActiveResource

version.body:
This patch introduced a regression my app's tests because our activeresource mocks did not set a content-type header. This was easy enough to fix once I debugged it, but it was pretty nasty to track down since the result is simply that the error messages are ignored and save returns true and the object appears valid with no trace of what happened without debugging deep into ActiveResource. Even though in production this case ought to never happen, in tests it's the default with no indication that you would need to set a Content-Type header.
The bottom line in my opinion is that any case where a 422 response is returned, the object should end up as invalid.
Although I'm not sure that defaulting to XML is "correct" or complete, I think we should do it to maintain backwards compatibility.
At the very least the ActiveResource::HttpMock documentation should show an example of stubbing an error.
What does everyone think?
version.body-html:
This patch introduced a regression my app's tests because our activeresource mocks did not set a content-type header. This was easy enough to fix once I debugged it, but it was pretty nasty to track down since the result is simply that the error messages are ignored and save returns true and the object appears valid with no trace of what happened without debugging deep into ActiveResource. Even though in production this case ought to never happen, in tests it's the default with no indication that you would need to set a Content-Type header.

The bottom line in my opinion is that any case where a 422 response is returned, the object should end up as invalid.

Although I'm not sure that defaulting to XML is "correct" or complete, I think we should do it to maintain backwards compatibility.

At the very least the ActiveResource::HttpMock documentation should show an example of stubbing an error.

What does everyone think?
version.tag: 2-3-stable 2.3.x 2.x 3.0 activeresource active_resource json patch validation validations
version.title: [PATCH] json validations errors for ActiveResource

version.body: Agreed, Gabe.
version.body-html: Agreed, Gabe.

version.tag: 2-3-stable 2.3.x 2.x 3.0 activeresource active_resource json patch validation validations
version.title: [PATCH] json validations errors for ActiveResource

version.body:
To avoid the problem faced by Gabe, the solution is to verify the format of ARes rather than Content-Type header for the remote errors.
I've attached patches for master and 2-3-stable.
version.body-html:
To avoid the problem faced by Gabe, the solution is to verify the format of ARes rather than Content-Type header for the remote errors.

I've attached patches for master and 2-3-stable.
version.tag: 2-3-stable 2.3.x 2.x 3.0 activeresource active_resource json patch validation validations
version.title: [PATCH] json validations errors for ActiveResource

version.title: [PATCH] json validations errors for ActiveResource

version.body:
(from [158e7b63ab83dbcb9cdc7f951be920faf16fe3c0]) Use format of ARes rather than content-type of remote errors to load errors.
[#1956 state:committed]
Signed-off-by: Jeremy Kemper <jeremy@bitsweat.net> http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/158e7b63ab83dbcb9cdc7f951be920faf16fe3c0
version.body-html:
(from [158e7b63ab83dbcb9cdc7f951be920faf16fe3c0]) Use format of ARes rather than content-type of remote errors to load errors.

[#1956 state:committed]

Signed-off-by: Jeremy Kemper jeremy@bitsweat.net
http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/158e7b63ab83dbcb9cdc7f951be920...

version.body: designer replica handbags have become from more than a necessity to more of a fashion accessory. For ages now, women have been changing their fashion trends in clothes. This stands true for the fashion trends in their designer replica handbags as well. The changing styles in designer handbags that constituted the clutch style purses, oversized coach handbags, the hermes replica handbags, the satchel, the tote, the duffel to name a few are just a glimpse of how each style is unique in their own way and are hugely popular among ladies all over the world. Women are becoming more fashion conscious day-by-day due to the spread of media and the stress on celebrity fashion enhanced with a lot of hype on the prada handbags they sport. Everyone just dies to own a designer dior handbags but what people tend to forget is one should not exceed their limits in affordabilitys of certain luxuries in life that they can do without. ysl handbags come to the rescue of this situation in terms that these d&g handbags are highly affordable and yet they have the same appeal in them that the miu miu replica has. So when one can get the designs of their desire at cheaper rates then why go for its extravagant version just because it sports the name tag of the designer. Many of these celine bags may be very small in size and dont really serve the actual purpose of mulberry replica but they just look like a prize catch with their gorgeous designs. However, if you choose to pay exuberant prices for dior bags that doesnt even serve a basic storage purpose what would you do after a certain period of time when it goes out of fashion? You cannot just expect to carry around the same valentino handbags to all occasions and expect your friends to appreciate it again and again. The point here is that, ysl bags are mainly bought to show off the designer tag and that you are a faithful customer of that designer and that makes you a person of exceptional caliber and class. jimmy choo handbags have no difference in the looks criteria and they look exactly like a designer or any other branded mulberry bayswater. They are just manufactured in bulk and their prices comprise of their production cost only wherein no price is associated with a so called name tag. This makes it a highly economical and profitable choice of goods and saves you ample of money to shop more. You can in fact own more than one replica designer paul smith bag and match each of them according to your look or attire on any given day. Since designer jimmy choo replica handbags burn a hole in your pocket you cannot just buy too many of them and wear them according to the burberry replica. So replica coach is yet another advantage of replica burberry handbags and also these versace handbags are such good coach replica handbags in the true sense that no one really identifies the louis vuitton replica from the original. These louis vuitton replica handbags are readily available online at even more discounted rates and they offer you attractive deals for the same. You can always recommend your friends and neighbors about your smart move and they would appreciate your input in helping them save their hard earned money as well.
